segment.source: Define the main game object
segment.target: Define the main game object

segment.source: Now, we look at the details of the game sample's main object and how the rules it implements translate into interactions with the game world.
segment.target: Now, we look at the details of the game sample's main object and how the rules it implements translate into interactions with the game world.

segment.source: Define the main game object
segment.target: Define the main game object

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: At this point, we've laid out the basic framework of the sample game, and we implemented a state machine that handles the high-level user and system behaviors.
segment.target: At this point, we've laid out the basic framework of the sample game, and we implemented a state machine that handles the high-level user and system behaviors.

segment.source: But we haven't examined the part that makes the game sample an actual game: the rules and mechanics, and how they're implemented!
segment.target: But we haven't examined the part that makes the game sample an actual game: the rules and mechanics, and how they're implemented!

segment.source: Now, we look at the details of the game sample's main object and how the rules it implements translate into interactions with the game world.
segment.target: Now, we look at the details of the game sample's main object and how the rules it implements translate into interactions with the game world.

segment.source: Objective
segment.target: Objective

segment.source: To apply the basic development techniques when implementing the rules and mechanics of a simple Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game using DirectX.
segment.target: To apply the basic development techniques when implementing the rules and mechanics of a simple Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game using DirectX.

segment.source: Considering the game's flow
segment.target: Considering the game's flow

segment.source: The majority of the game's basic structure is defined in these files:
segment.target: The majority of the game's basic structure is defined in these files:

segment.source: App.cpp
segment.target: App.cpp

segment.source: Simple3DGame.cpp
segment.target: Simple3DGame.cpp

segment.source: In Defining the game's UWP app framework, we reviewed the game framework defined in App.cpp.
segment.target: In Defining the game's UWP app framework, we reviewed the game framework defined in App.cpp.

segment.source: Simple3DGame.cpp provides the code for a class, Simple3DGame, which specifies the implementation of the game play itself.
segment.target: Simple3DGame.cpp provides the code for a class, Simple3DGame, which specifies the implementation of the game play itself.

segment.source: Earlier, we considered the treatment of the sample game as a UWP app.
segment.target: Earlier, we considered the treatment of the sample game as a UWP app.

segment.source: Now, we look at the code that makes it a game.
segment.target: Now, we look at the code that makes it a game.

segment.source: The complete code for Simple3DGame.h/.cpp is provided in Complete sample code for this section.
segment.target: The complete code for Simple3DGame.h/.cpp is provided in Complete sample code for this section.

segment.source: Let's take a look at the definition of the Simple3DGame class.
segment.target: Let's take a look at the definition of the Simple3DGame class.

segment.source: Defining the core game object
segment.target: Defining the core game object

segment.source: When the app singleton starts, the view provider's Initialize method creates an instance of the main game class, the Simple3DGame object.
segment.target: When the app singleton starts, the view provider's Initialize method creates an instance of the main game class, the Simple3DGame object.

segment.source: This object contains the methods that communicate changes in game state to the state machine defined in the app framework, or from the app to the game object itself.
segment.target: This object contains the methods that communicate changes in game state to the state machine defined in the app framework, or from the app to the game object itself.

segment.source: It also contains methods that return info for updating the game's overlay bitmap and heads-up display, and for updating the animations and physics (the dynamics) in the game.
segment.target: It also contains methods that return info for updating the game's overlay bitmap and heads-up display, and for updating the animations and physics (the dynamics) in the game.

segment.source: The code for obtaining the graphics device resources used by the game is found in GameRenderer.cpp, which we discuss next in Assembling the rendering framework.
segment.target: The code for obtaining the graphics device resources used by the game is found in GameRenderer.cpp, which we discuss next in Assembling the rendering framework.

segment.source: The code for Simple3DGame looks like this:
segment.target: The code for Simple3DGame looks like this:

segment.source: First, let's review the internal methods defined on Simple3DGame.
segment.target: First, let's review the internal methods defined on Simple3DGame.

segment.source: Initialize.
segment.target: Initialize.

segment.source: Sets the starting values of the global variables and initializes the game objects.
segment.target: Sets the starting values of the global variables and initializes the game objects.

segment.source: LoadGame.
segment.target: LoadGame.

segment.source: Initializes a new level and starts loading it.
segment.target: Initializes a new level and starts loading it.

segment.source: LoadLevelAsync.
segment.target: LoadLevelAsync.

segment.source: Starts an async task (see the Parallel Patterns Library for more details) to initialize the level and then invoke an async task on the renderer to load the device specific level resources.
segment.target: Starts an async task (see the Parallel Patterns Library for more details) to initialize the level and then invoke an async task on the renderer to load the device specific level resources.

segment.source: This method runs in a separate thread; as a result, only ID3D11Device methods (as opposed to ID3D11DeviceContext methods) can be called from this thread.
segment.target: This method runs in a separate thread; as a result, only ID3D11Device methods (as opposed to ID3D11DeviceContext methods) can be called from this thread.

segment.source: Any device context methods are called in the FinalizeLoadLevel method.
segment.target: Any device context methods are called in the FinalizeLoadLevel method.

segment.source: FinalizeLoadLevel.
segment.target: FinalizeLoadLevel.

segment.source: Completes any work for level loading that needs to be done on the main thread.
segment.target: Completes any work for level loading that needs to be done on the main thread.

segment.source: This includes any calls to Direct3D 11 device context (ID3D11DeviceContext) methods.
segment.target: This includes any calls to Direct3D 11 device context (ID3D11DeviceContext) methods.

segment.source: StartLevel.
segment.target: StartLevel.

segment.source: Starts the game play for a new level.
segment.target: Starts the game play for a new level.

segment.source: PauseGame.
segment.target: PauseGame.

segment.source: Pauses the game.
segment.target: Pauses the game.

segment.source: RunGame.
segment.target: RunGame.

segment.source: Runs an iteration of the game loop.
segment.target: Runs an iteration of the game loop.

segment.source: It's called from App::Update one time every iteration of the game loop if the game state is Active.
segment.target: It's called from App::Update one time every iteration of the game loop if the game state is Active.

segment.source: OnSuspending and OnResuming.
segment.target: OnSuspending and OnResuming.

segment.source: Suspends and resumes the game's audio, respectively.
segment.target: Suspends and resumes the game's audio, respectively.

segment.source: And the private methods:
segment.target: And the private methods:

segment.source: LoadSavedState and SaveState.
segment.target: LoadSavedState and SaveState.

segment.source: Loads and saves the current state of the game, respectively.
segment.target: Loads and saves the current state of the game, respectively.

segment.source: SaveHighScore and LoadHighScore.
segment.target: SaveHighScore and LoadHighScore.

segment.source: Saves and loads the high score across games, respectively.
segment.target: Saves and loads the high score across games, respectively.

segment.source: InitializeAmmo.
segment.target: InitializeAmmo.

segment.source: Resets the state of each sphere object used as ammunition back to its original state for the beginning of each round.
segment.target: Resets the state of each sphere object used as ammunition back to its original state for the beginning of each round.

segment.source: UpdateDynamics.
segment.target: UpdateDynamics.

segment.source: This is an important method, because it updates all the game objects based on canned animation routines, physics, and control input.
segment.target: This is an important method, because it updates all the game objects based on canned animation routines, physics, and control input.

segment.source: This is the heart of the interactivity that defines the game.
segment.target: This is the heart of the interactivity that defines the game.

segment.source: We talk about it more in the Updating the game section.
segment.target: We talk about it more in the Updating the game section.

segment.source: The other public methods are property getters that return game play and overlay specific information to the app framework for display.
segment.target: The other public methods are property getters that return game play and overlay specific information to the app framework for display.

segment.source: Defining the game state variables
segment.target: Defining the game state variables

segment.source: One function of the game object is to serve as a container for the data that defines a game session, level, or lifetime, depending on how you define your game at a high level.
segment.target: One function of the game object is to serve as a container for the data that defines a game session, level, or lifetime, depending on how you define your game at a high level.

segment.source: In this case, the game state data is for the lifetime of the game, initialized one time when a user launches the game.
segment.target: In this case, the game state data is for the lifetime of the game, initialized one time when a user launches the game.

segment.source: Here's the complete set of definitions for the game object's state variables.
segment.target: Here's the complete set of definitions for the game object's state variables.

segment.source: At the top of the code example, there are four objects whose instances are updated as the game loop runs.
segment.target: At the top of the code example, there are four objects whose instances are updated as the game loop runs.

segment.source: The MoveLookController object.
segment.target: The MoveLookController object.

segment.source: This object represents the player input.
segment.target: This object represents the player input.

segment.source: (For more info about the MoveLookController object, see Adding controls.)
segment.target: (For more info about the MoveLookController object, see Adding controls.)

segment.source: The GameRenderer object.
segment.target: The GameRenderer object.

segment.source: This object represents the Direct3D 11 renderer derived from the DirectXBase class that handles all the device-specific objects and their rendering.
segment.target: This object represents the Direct3D 11 renderer derived from the DirectXBase class that handles all the device-specific objects and their rendering.

segment.source: (For more info, see Assembling the rendering pipeline).
segment.target: (For more info, see Assembling the rendering pipeline).

segment.source: The Camera object.
segment.target: The Camera object.

segment.source: This object represents the player's first-person view of the game world.
segment.target: This object represents the player's first-person view of the game world.

segment.source: (For more info about the Camera object, see Assembling the rendering pipeline.)
segment.target: (For more info about the Camera object, see Assembling the rendering pipeline.)

segment.source: The Audio object.
segment.target: The Audio object.

segment.source: This object controls the audio playback for the game.
segment.target: This object controls the audio playback for the game.

segment.source: (For more info about the Audio object, see Adding sound.)
segment.target: (For more info about the Audio object, see Adding sound.)

segment.source: The rest of the game variables contain the lists of the primitives and their respective in-game amounts, and game play specific data and constraints.
segment.target: The rest of the game variables contain the lists of the primitives and their respective in-game amounts, and game play specific data and constraints.

segment.source: Let's see how the sample configures these variables when the game is initialized.
segment.target: Let's see how the sample configures these variables when the game is initialized.

segment.source: Initializing and starting the game
segment.target: Initializing and starting the game

segment.source: When a player starts the game, the game object must initialize its state, create and add the overlay, set the variables that track the player's performance, and instantiate the objects that it will use to build the levels.
segment.target: When a player starts the game, the game object must initialize its state, create and add the overlay, set the variables that track the player's performance, and instantiate the objects that it will use to build the levels.

segment.source: The sample game sets up the components of the game object in this order:
segment.target: The sample game sets up the components of the game object in this order:

segment.source: A new audio playback object is created.
segment.target: A new audio playback object is created.

segment.source: Arrays for the game's graphic primitives are created, including arrays for the level primitives, ammo, and obstacles.
segment.target: Arrays for the game's graphic primitives are created, including arrays for the level primitives, ammo, and obstacles.

segment.source: A location for saving game state data is created, named Game, and placed in the app data settings storage location specified by ApplicationData::Current.
segment.target: A location for saving game state data is created, named Game, and placed in the app data settings storage location specified by ApplicationData::Current.

segment.source: A game timer and the initial in-game overlay bitmap are created.
segment.target: A game timer and the initial in-game overlay bitmap are created.

segment.source: A new camera is created with a specific set of view and projection parameters.
segment.target: A new camera is created with a specific set of view and projection parameters.

segment.source: The input device (the controller) is set to the same starting pitch and yaw as the camera, so the player has a 1-to-1 correspondence between the starting control position and the camera position.
segment.target: The input device (the controller) is set to the same starting pitch and yaw as the camera, so the player has a 1-to-1 correspondence between the starting control position and the camera position.

segment.source: The player object is created and set to active.
segment.target: The player object is created and set to active.

segment.source: We use a sphere object to detect the player's proximity to walls and obstacles and to keep the camera from getting put in a position that might break immersion.
segment.target: We use a sphere object to detect the player's proximity to walls and obstacles and to keep the camera from getting put in a position that might break immersion.

segment.source: The game world primitive is created.
segment.target: The game world primitive is created.

segment.source: The cylinder obstacles are created.
segment.target: The cylinder obstacles are created.

segment.source: The targets (Face objects) are created and numbered.
segment.target: The targets (Face objects) are created and numbered.

segment.source: The ammo spheres are created.
segment.target: The ammo spheres are created.

segment.source: The levels are created.
segment.target: The levels are created.

segment.source: The high score is loaded.
segment.target: The high score is loaded.

segment.source: Any prior saved game state is loaded.
segment.target: Any prior saved game state is loaded.

segment.source: The game now has instances of all the key components: the world, the player, the obstacles, the targets, and the ammo spheres.
segment.target: The game now has instances of all the key components: the world, the player, the obstacles, the targets, and the ammo spheres.

segment.source: It also has instances of the levels, which represent configurations of all of the above components and their behaviors for each specific level.
segment.target: It also has instances of the levels, which represent configurations of all of the above components and their behaviors for each specific level.

segment.source: Let's see how the game builds the levels.
segment.target: Let's see how the game builds the levels.

segment.source: Building and loading the game's levels
segment.target: Building and loading the game's levels

segment.source: Most of the heavy lifting for the level construction is done in the Level.h/.cpp file, which we won't delve into, because it focuses on a very specific implementation.
segment.target: Most of the heavy lifting for the level construction is done in the Level.h/.cpp file, which we won't delve into, because it focuses on a very specific implementation.

segment.source: The important thing is that the code for each level is run as a separate LevelN object.
segment.target: The important thing is that the code for each level is run as a separate LevelN object.

segment.source: If you'd like to extend the game, you can create a Level object that took an assigned number as a parameter and randomly placed the obstacles and targets.
segment.target: If you'd like to extend the game, you can create a Level object that took an assigned number as a parameter and randomly placed the obstacles and targets.

segment.source: Or, you can have it load level configuration data from a resource file, or even the Internet!
segment.target: Or, you can have it load level configuration data from a resource file, or even the Internet!

segment.source: The complete code for Level.h/.cpp is provided in Complete sample code for this section.
segment.target: The complete code for Level.h/.cpp is provided in Complete sample code for this section.

segment.source: Defining the game play
segment.target: Defining the game play

segment.source: At this point, we have all the components we need to assemble the game.
segment.target: At this point, we have all the components we need to assemble the game.

segment.source: The levels have been constructed in memory from the primitives, and are ready for the player to start interacting with them in some fashion.
segment.target: The levels have been constructed in memory from the primitives, and are ready for the player to start interacting with them in some fashion.

segment.source: Now, the best games react instantly to player input, and provide immediate feedback.
segment.target: Now, the best games react instantly to player input, and provide immediate feedback.

segment.source: This is true for any type of a game, from twitch-action, real-time shoot-em-ups to thoughtful, turn-based strategy games.
segment.target: This is true for any type of a game, from twitch-action, real-time shoot-em-ups to thoughtful, turn-based strategy games.

segment.source: In Defining the game's UWP framework, we looked at the overall state machine that governs the flow of the game.
segment.target: In Defining the game's UWP framework, we looked at the overall state machine that governs the flow of the game.

segment.source: Remember, the sample implements this flow as a loop inside the Run method of the App class, which itself is an implementation of a DirectX view provider.
segment.target: Remember, the sample implements this flow as a loop inside the Run method of the App class, which itself is an implementation of a DirectX view provider.

segment.source: The important state transitions must be controlled by the player, and must provide clear feedback.
segment.target: The important state transitions must be controlled by the player, and must provide clear feedback.

segment.source: Any delay in this feedback breaks the sense of immersion.
segment.target: Any delay in this feedback breaks the sense of immersion.

segment.source: Here is a diagram representing the basic flow of the game and its high-level states.
segment.target: Here is a diagram representing the basic flow of the game and its high-level states.

segment.source: a diagram showing the main state machine for our game
segment.target: a diagram showing the main state machine for our game

segment.source: When the sample game starts play, the game object can be in one of three states:
segment.target: When the sample game starts play, the game object can be in one of three states:

segment.source: Waiting for resources.
segment.target: Waiting for resources.

segment.source: This state is activated when the game object is initialized or when the components of a level are being loaded.
segment.target: This state is activated when the game object is initialized or when the components of a level are being loaded.

segment.source: If this state was triggered by a request to load a prior game, the game stats overlay is displayed; if it was triggered by a request to play a level, the level start overlay is displayed.
segment.target: If this state was triggered by a request to load a prior game, the game stats overlay is displayed; if it was triggered by a request to play a level, the level start overlay is displayed.

segment.source: The completion of resource loading causes the game to pass through the Resources loaded state and then transition into the Waiting for press state.
segment.target: The completion of resource loading causes the game to pass through the Resources loaded state and then transition into the Waiting for press state.

segment.source: Waiting for press.
segment.target: Waiting for press.

segment.source: This state is activated when the game is paused, either by the player or by the system (after, say, loading resources).
segment.target: This state is activated when the game is paused, either by the player or by the system (after, say, loading resources).

segment.source: When the player is ready to exit this state, the player is prompted to load a new game state (LoadGame), start or restart the loaded level (StartLevel), or continue the current level (ContinueGame).
segment.target: When the player is ready to exit this state, the player is prompted to load a new game state (LoadGame), start or restart the loaded level (StartLevel), or continue the current level (ContinueGame).

segment.source: Dynamics.
segment.target: Dynamics.

segment.source: If a player's press input is completed and the resulting action is to start or continue a level, the game object transitions into the Dynamics state.
segment.target: If a player's press input is completed and the resulting action is to start or continue a level, the game object transitions into the Dynamics state.

segment.source: The game is played in this state, and the game world and player objects are updated here based on animation routines and player input.
segment.target: The game is played in this state, and the game world and player objects are updated here based on animation routines and player input.

segment.source: This state is left when the player triggers a pause event, either by pressing P, by taking an action that deactivates the main window, or by completing a level or the game.
segment.target: This state is left when the player triggers a pause event, either by pressing P, by taking an action that deactivates the main window, or by completing a level or the game.

segment.source: Now, let's look at specific code in the App class (see: Defining the game's UWP framework) for the Update method that implements this state machine.
segment.target: Now, let's look at specific code in the App class (see: Defining the game's UWP framework) for the Update method that implements this state machine.

segment.source: The first thing this method does is call the MoveLookController instance's own Update method, which updates the data from the controller.
segment.target: The first thing this method does is call the MoveLookController instance's own Update method, which updates the data from the controller.

segment.source: This data includes the direction the player's view (the camera) is facing and the velocity of the player's movement.
segment.target: This data includes the direction the player's view (the camera) is facing and the velocity of the player's movement.

segment.source: When the game is in the Dynamics state, that is, when the player is playing, the work is handled in the RunGame method, with this call:
segment.target: When the game is in the Dynamics state, that is, when the player is playing, the work is handled in the RunGame method, with this call:

segment.source: RunGame handles the set of data that defines the current state of the game play for the current iteration of the game loop.
segment.target: RunGame handles the set of data that defines the current state of the game play for the current iteration of the game loop.

segment.source: It flows like this:
segment.target: It flows like this:

segment.source: The method updates the timer that counts down the seconds until the level is completed, and tests to see if the level's time has expired.
segment.target: The method updates the timer that counts down the seconds until the level is completed, and tests to see if the level's time has expired.

segment.source: This is one of the rules of the game: when time runs out without all the targets getting shot, the game is over.
segment.target: This is one of the rules of the game: when time runs out without all the targets getting shot, the game is over.

segment.source: If time has run out, the method sets the TimeExpired game state, and returns to the Update method in the previous code.
segment.target: If time has run out, the method sets the TimeExpired game state, and returns to the Update method in the previous code.

segment.source: If time remains, the move-look controller is polled for an update to the camera position; specifically, an update to the angle of the view normal projecting from the camera plane (where the player is looking), and the distance that angle has moved from the previous time the controller was polled.
segment.target: If time remains, the move-look controller is polled for an update to the camera position; specifically, an update to the angle of the view normal projecting from the camera plane (where the player is looking), and the distance that angle has moved from the previous time the controller was polled.

segment.source: The camera is updated based on the new data from the move-look controller.
segment.target: The camera is updated based on the new data from the move-look controller.

segment.source: The dynamics, or the animations and behaviors of objects in the game world independent of player control, are updated.
segment.target: The dynamics, or the animations and behaviors of objects in the game world independent of player control, are updated.

segment.source: In the game sample, this is the motion of the ammo spheres that have been fired, the animation of the pillar obstacles and the movement of the targets.
segment.target: In the game sample, this is the motion of the ammo spheres that have been fired, the animation of the pillar obstacles and the movement of the targets.

segment.source: The method checks to see if the criteria for the successful completion of a level have been met.
segment.target: The method checks to see if the criteria for the successful completion of a level have been met.

segment.source: If so, it finalizes the score for the level and checks to see if this is the last level (of 6).
segment.target: If so, it finalizes the score for the level and checks to see if this is the last level (of 6).

segment.source: If it's the last level, the method returns the GameComplete game state; otherwise, it returns the LevelComplete game state.
segment.target: If it's the last level, the method returns the GameComplete game state; otherwise, it returns the LevelComplete game state.

segment.source: If the level isn't complete, the method sets the game state to Active and returns.
segment.target: If the level isn't complete, the method sets the game state to Active and returns.

segment.source: Here's what RunGame, found in Simple3DGame.cpp, looks like in code.
segment.target: Here's what RunGame, found in Simple3DGame.cpp, looks like in code.

segment.source: Here's the key call: .
segment.target: Here's the key call: .

segment.source: It's what brings the game world to life.
segment.target: It's what brings the game world to life.

segment.source: Let's review it!
segment.target: Let's review it!

segment.source: Updating the game world
segment.target: Updating the game world

segment.source: A fast and fluid game experience is one where the world feels alive, where the game itself is in motion independent of player input.
segment.target: A fast and fluid game experience is one where the world feels alive, where the game itself is in motion independent of player input.

segment.source: Trees wave in the wind, waves crest along shore lines, machinery smokes and shines, and alien monsters stretch and salivate.
segment.target: Trees wave in the wind, waves crest along shore lines, machinery smokes and shines, and alien monsters stretch and salivate.

segment.source: Imagine what a game would be like if everything was frozen, with the graphics only moving when the player provided input.
segment.target: Imagine what a game would be like if everything was frozen, with the graphics only moving when the player provided input.

segment.source: It'd be weird and not very, well, immersive.
segment.target: It'd be weird and not very, well, immersive.

segment.source: Immersion, for the player, comes from the feeling of being an agent in a living, breathing world.
segment.target: Immersion, for the player, comes from the feeling of being an agent in a living, breathing world.

segment.source: The game loop should always keep updating the game world and running the animation routines, be they canned or based on physical algorithms or just plain random, except when the game is specifically paused.
segment.target: The game loop should always keep updating the game world and running the animation routines, be they canned or based on physical algorithms or just plain random, except when the game is specifically paused.

segment.source: In the game sample, this principle is called dynamics, and it encompasses the rise and fall of the pillar obstacles, and the motion and physical behaviors of the ammo spheres as they are fired.
segment.target: In the game sample, this principle is called dynamics, and it encompasses the rise and fall of the pillar obstacles, and the motion and physical behaviors of the ammo spheres as they are fired.

segment.source: It also encompasses the interaction between objects, including collisions between the player sphere and the world, or between the ammo and the obstacles and targets.
segment.target: It also encompasses the interaction between objects, including collisions between the player sphere and the world, or between the ammo and the obstacles and targets.

segment.source: The code that implements these dynamics looks like this:
segment.target: The code that implements these dynamics looks like this:

segment.source: (This code example has been abbreviated for readability.
segment.target: (This code example has been abbreviated for readability.

segment.source: The full working code is found in the complete code sample at the bottom of this topic.)
segment.target: The full working code is found in the complete code sample at the bottom of this topic.)

segment.source: This method deals with four sets of computations:
segment.target: This method deals with four sets of computations:

segment.source: The positions of the fired ammo spheres in the world.
segment.target: The positions of the fired ammo spheres in the world.

segment.source: The animation of the pillar obstacles.
segment.target: The animation of the pillar obstacles.

segment.source: The intersection of the player and the world boundaries.
segment.target: The intersection of the player and the world boundaries.

segment.source: The collisions of the ammo spheres with the obstacles, the targets, other ammo spheres, and the world.
segment.target: The collisions of the ammo spheres with the obstacles, the targets, other ammo spheres, and the world.

segment.source: The animation of the obstacles is a loop defined in Animate.h/.cpp.
segment.target: The animation of the obstacles is a loop defined in Animate.h/.cpp.

segment.source: The behavior of the ammo and any collisions are defined by simplified physics algorithms, supplied in the previous code and parameterized by a set of global constants for the game world, including gravity and material properties.
segment.target: The behavior of the ammo and any collisions are defined by simplified physics algorithms, supplied in the previous code and parameterized by a set of global constants for the game world, including gravity and material properties.

segment.source: This is all computed in the game world coordinate space.
segment.target: This is all computed in the game world coordinate space.

segment.source: Now that we've updated all the objects in the scene and calculated any collisions, we need to use that info to draw the corresponding visual changes.
segment.target: Now that we've updated all the objects in the scene and calculated any collisions, we need to use that info to draw the corresponding visual changes.

segment.source: After Update completes in the current iteration of the game loop, the sample immediately calls Render to take the updated object data and generate a new scene to present to the player.
segment.target: After Update completes in the current iteration of the game loop, the sample immediately calls Render to take the updated object data and generate a new scene to present to the player.

segment.source: Let's look at the render method now.
segment.target: Let's look at the render method now.

segment.source: Rendering the game world's graphics
segment.target: Rendering the game world's graphics

segment.source: We recommend that the graphics in a game update as often as possible, which, at maximum, is every time the main game loop iterates.
segment.target: We recommend that the graphics in a game update as often as possible, which, at maximum, is every time the main game loop iterates.

segment.source: As the loop iterates, the game is updated, with or without player input.
segment.target: As the loop iterates, the game is updated, with or without player input.

segment.source: This allows the animations and behaviors that are calculated to be displayed smoothly.
segment.target: This allows the animations and behaviors that are calculated to be displayed smoothly.

segment.source: Imagine if we had a simple scene of water that only moved when the player pressed a button.
segment.target: Imagine if we had a simple scene of water that only moved when the player pressed a button.

segment.source: That would make for terribly boring visuals.
segment.target: That would make for terribly boring visuals.

segment.source: A good game looks smooth and fluid.
segment.target: A good game looks smooth and fluid.

segment.source: Recall the sample game's loop, as shown here.
segment.target: Recall the sample game's loop, as shown here.

segment.source: If the game's main window is visible, and isn't snapped or deactivated, the game continues to update and render the results of that update.
segment.target: If the game's main window is visible, and isn't snapped or deactivated, the game continues to update and render the results of that update.

segment.source: The method we examine now renders a representation of that state immediately after the state is updated in Run with a call to Update, which we discussed in the previous section.
segment.target: The method we examine now renders a representation of that state immediately after the state is updated in Run with a call to Update, which we discussed in the previous section.

segment.source: The complete code for this method is in Assembling the rendering framework.
segment.target: The complete code for this method is in Assembling the rendering framework.

segment.source: This method draws the projection of the 3D world, and then draws the Direct2D overlay on top of it.
segment.target: This method draws the projection of the 3D world, and then draws the Direct2D overlay on top of it.

segment.source: When completed, it presents the final swap chain with the combined buffers for display.
segment.target: When completed, it presents the final swap chain with the combined buffers for display.

segment.source: Be aware that there are two states for the sample game's Direct2D overlay: one where the game displays the game info overlay that contains the bitmap for the pause menu, and one where the game displays the cross hairs along with the rectangles for the touchscreen move-look controller.
segment.target: Be aware that there are two states for the sample game's Direct2D overlay: one where the game displays the game info overlay that contains the bitmap for the pause menu, and one where the game displays the cross hairs along with the rectangles for the touchscreen move-look controller.

segment.source: The score text is drawn in both states.
segment.target: The score text is drawn in both states.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: By now, you're probably curious about the actual rendering engine: how those calls to the Render methods on the updated primitives get turned into pixels on your screen.
segment.target: By now, you're probably curious about the actual rendering engine: how those calls to the Render methods on the updated primitives get turned into pixels on your screen.

segment.source: We cover that in detail in Assembling the rendering framework.
segment.target: We cover that in detail in Assembling the rendering framework.

segment.source: If you're more interested in how the player controls update the game state, then check out Adding controls.
segment.target: If you're more interested in how the player controls update the game state, then check out Adding controls.
